title: Synthetic Recap
body:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) — On a night where one player authored a performance for the ages, it was his final, defiant act that carved his name into the stone of NBA lore.

The Philadelphia 76ers, led by a herculean and record-setting 50 points from Jerry Stackhouse, seemed destined for victory. The Spectrum crowd, having witnessed their star pour in a scoring barrage unlike any they had seen against Washington, roared with every basket. Stackhouse was unstoppable, a force of nature carrying his team on his back. He didn't just score; he dominated, adding 9 rebounds and 6 assists to his historic point total.

Yet, for all his brilliance, the final chapter belonged to Gheorghe Muresan.

In a game defined by one man's offensive explosion, it was a defensive stop by the 7-foot-7 Romanian center that sealed a stunning 107-106 victory for the Washington Bullets. With the seconds evaporating and the Sixers poised for a game-winning attempt, Muresan rose to his impossible height, swatting away a final shot to preserve the slimmest of margins.

The Bullets, who saw balanced scoring with Chris Webber’s 21 points and Calbert Cheaney’s 20, had weathered the Stackhouse storm. They clawed, they battled, and they stayed within striking distance of a one-man wrecking crew. But when the final horn sounded, the story was no longer about the 50 points scored, but about the one shot that was denied.

Stackhouse’s masterpiece, a career-high and franchise-record effort, was reduced to a heartbreaking footnote. On this night, the stat sheet will forever show his 50 points, but the scoreboard, and history, will show a different, more cruel truth: sometimes, even a superhuman performance isn't enough.
